Composable Python Applications with wired

Inversion of Control (IoC) and Dependency Injection (DI) are popular patterns for maintainable applications. wired is a scalable Python library for building decoupled, extensible, configurable, pluggable applications.

Make some entity

class Greeter:
    def __init__(self, greeting):
        self.greeting = greeting

    def __call__(self):
        return f'{self.greeting} !!'

Register it

registry = ServiceRegistry()

# Greeters are nice...they greet people!
greeter = Greeter(greeting='Hello')

# Register it as a singleton using its class for the "key"
registry.register_singleton(greeter, Greeter)

Make a callable that uses it

def greet_a_customer(container):

    # Get the registered greeter, do the greeting
    the_greeter = container.get(Greeter)
    greeting = the_greeter()

    return greeting

Then use it in an operation

# A customer comes in, handle the steps in the greeting process
# as a "container".
container = registry.create_container()
greeting = greet_a_customer(container)

# The "request" was handled, return it
print(greeting)

Scalable

Scale down to "hello world", up to large systems

Other libraries usually turn into frameworks which turn into monoliths. wired is a good fit for even small applications, but shines as you scale.

  • One dependency, which itself has one dependency
  • Core wired is very small
  • Lets you build custom apps atop it

Tired of passing the universe around? wired makes it easy for the callee to decide what pieces it wants from the caller.

  • Ideal for writing in-house frameworks with pluggable pieces
  • Easy to write tests by replacing the the parts used by tested code

Decoupled

Keep your app's core and code written for it at arm's length.
